author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What You May Not Know About Those April Flowers
description: Americans have cultivated nonnative plants and flowers for so long it has skewed our experience of spring.
content: NASHVILLE — My favorite spring flower blooms along the leafless branches of the lowly serviceberry, a small tree with varieties native to every state except Hawaii. In the old days, the serviceberry’s simple, five-petaled blossoms heralded springtime itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: His Plane Crashed in the Amazon. Then Came the Hard Part.
description: A Brazilian pilot working for wildcat miners escaped death when his plane went down in a remote area. He walked through the jungle for 36 days before being rescued.
content: This story was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center’s Rainforest Investigations Network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Cases in Florida, a national Covid bellwether, are rising — especially among younger people.
description: The state’s open invitation to enjoy spring break is a contributing factor. Another may be the exponential increase of infections of the more contagious B.1.1.7 variant.
content: Scientists view Florida — the state furthest along in lifting restrictions, reopening society and welcoming tourists — as a bellwether for the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: On Hallowed Ground
description: The spot in Minneapolis where George Floyd was killed speaks to those who visit.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — I arrived in Minneapolis on a rainy Saturday, the city quiet and still, in the calm before the storm. It is a city changed, scarred and shifted, in anticipation and apprehension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Umansky
title: Find a Headline, Write a Poem
description: A form called the Golden Shovel honors the poet Gwendolyn Brooks, and you just need a newspaper to get started.
content: Celebration and honor are two touchstones of the poetic tradition. With April’s National Poetry Month approaching, let’s write a poem in honor of another poem, and another poet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Myanmar’s bloodiest day.
content: Saturday appeared to be the bloodiest day of protests since the Feb. 1 military coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Take a Drawing Class and Celebrate Easter With the White House
description: This week, tune in to a Buddhist ritual chant, learn about botanical art or make a new cocktail.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Trumpets Vaccine Exports, While Quietly Importing Doses
description: Russia has held up the Sputnik vaccine as a triumph of its scientists. But the country’s inoculation program still relies on cross-border trade.
content: MOSCOW — Russia has lauded with much fanfare the arrival of its homegrown vaccine, Sputnik V, in Latin America and Africa, and even in some countries in Europe, calling it a solution to shortages around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr
title: Vaccines, Suez Canal, Passover: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Tim Arango
title: Ten Months After George Floyd’s Death, Minneapolis Residents Are at War Over Policing
description: As the trial of a former officer accused of murdering Mr. Floyd starts, residents and community leaders have struggled to reach consensus on how to radically change public safety, and the role that the police should play in that.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The sacred intersection where George Floyd died beneath the knee of a police officer has seen such an increase in violence that food delivery drivers are afraid to venture there. There have been gun battles, with bloodied shooting victims dragged to ambulances because of barricades keeping the police and emergency vehicles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Biblical Mystery and a Reporting Odyssey
description: A question about pieces of a manuscript found in 1883 that may or may not be authentic led me into The Times’s archive.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: One-pot French onion soup, grilled salmon salad, ramen with charred scallions: Eat well in the days ahead.
content: Good morning. Today’s one of those days where it would be really nice to spend the whole day cooking: a big pot of beans for lunches next week; Cheddar beer bread rolls for dinner this evening; a carrot cake for dessert; deviled chicken thighs (above) for the meal, alongside this terrific new recipe for roasted broccoli glazed in butter and vinegar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: The Unstoppable Merry Clayton
description: One of music’s greatest backup singers is releasing “Beautiful Scars,” her first new album in over 25 years, after surviving an accident that proved that her incredible strength isn’t only in her voice.
content: In 1962, an excited 14-year-old Merry Clayton turned up for her first big recording session. After entering the storied Capitol Studios in Hollywood, she took her place among the other young women who had been called to sing backup for a Bobby Darin record. Soon after they started to sing their part of the song, however, Darin stopped the session cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chitnis
title: Brighten Up Easter With Naturally Dyed Eggs
description: Using ingredients straight from your kitchen, these dyed Easter eggs make a fun and festive way to celebrate.
content: Egg decorating is a festive activity that celebrates the arrival of spring, a season of renewal. The egg, an ancient symbol of rebirth and new life, has a long and storied history tied to holidays and seasonal celebrations around the world, including Easter. In fact, if you’ve hand-dyed eggs, then you have, perhaps unknowingly, participated in one of the oldest known decorative art forms. In 2010, archaeologists in South Africa discovered engraved ostrich eggs dating back around 60,000 years. Since then, eggs have been decorated in every way imaginable, including traditional pysanky (Ukrainian Easter egg decoration) and arts-and-craft inspired decoupage eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Edward Jenner Pioneered Vaccination. Will His Museum Survive a Pandemic?
description: The site where Dr. Jenner first inoculated people against smallpox has struggled in the coronavirus lockdowns, one of hundreds of museums in Britain teetering amid the closures.
content: BERKELEY, England — It has been called the birthplace of modern vaccination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Boyfriend and I Had Begun to Take Bike Rides Around Central Park’
description: An eerie sound, good seats for the circus and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.’, Maya Rudolph Hosts a Unity Seder as Kamala Harris
description: The “Saturday Night Live” alumna reprised her role as Vice President Kamala Harris in a sketch that also featured Alex Moffat’s return as President Biden.
content: This weekend, “Saturday Night Live” added one more question to the four that are customarily asked at a Passover Seder: Why wasn’t this sketch chosen as the cold open?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Six states are opening vaccination to all adults on Monday, with many residents eager for shots.
description: “We must get every dose of vaccine into arms quickly,” said Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas.
content: Chris Adams, 36, has spent the past year of the pandemic living with his grandparents in Wichita, Kan., and being “extremely strict” about social distancing. “I never went out,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Scholastic Halts Distribution of Book by ‘Captain Underpants’ Author
description: The book, “The Adventures of Ook and Gluk: Kung-Fu Cavemen from the Future” by Dav Pilkey, includes images and tropes that perpetuate “passive racism,” the publisher said.
content: A children’s graphic novel by the creator of the popular “Captain Underpants” series was pulled from circulation last week by its publisher, which said that it “perpetuates passive racism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson
title: How 2 Legislative Tacticians Scored Big Wins on Child Poverty in the Stimulus
description: After working for decades on the issue, Senator Patty Murray and Representative Rosa DeLauro teamed up to ensure that the stimulus law included a lifeline to the nation’s poorest families.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Biden stood in the Rose Garden this month, basking in the glow of his newly enacted $1.9 trillion stimulus package, he singled out two lawmakers who had been toiling away in relative obscurity on its key provisions for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Journalist Cleared of Defamation Charge Revives India’s #MeToo
description: A powerful politician sued Priya Ramani for criminal defamation after she accused him of sexual harassment. Women hope her clearing spurs a stalled movement.
content: — Priya Ramani, a journalist, on being cleared of wrongdoing in a defamation suit
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Inmate Is Killed in Hostage Standoff at Oklahoma Jail
description: A correction officer who had been taken hostage was rescued, officials said. The officer was injured and taken to a hospital.
content: An inmate was killed and a correction officer was injured after being taken hostage at the Oklahoma County Detention Center in Oklahoma City on Saturday, law enforcement officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Inside Myanmar’s Army: ‘They See Protesters as Criminals’
description: Four officers spoke about life in the feared Tatmadaw, which has turned its guns on civilians again. “The Tatmadaw is the only world” for most soldiers, one said.
content: Capt. Tun Myat Aung leaned over the hot pavement in Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city, and picked up bullet casings. Nausea crept into his throat. The shells, he knew, meant that rifles had been used, real bullets fired at real people.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Under Biden, Foreign Diplomacy Has Become a Coveted Career Again
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 28, 2021.
content: “I think there is a sense that America is back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Texas Upsets Maryland for Spot in the Round of 8
description: The Longhorns came back in the second half against the Terrapins. But other top-seeded teams in Sunday’s games claimed their spots.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Sixth-seeded Texas came back for a 64-61 win over No. 2 seed Maryland in a tight thriller that sent the Alamodome into a resounding roar, becoming the lowest seed of this year’s N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament to make it to the round of 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: ‘All Hands on Deck’: When Vaccinating Black People Is a Communal Effort
description: In the face of limited transportation, patchy internet service and threadbare medical care, community leaders in Alabama and Mississippi are trying to shrink the racial disparities in vaccine access.
content: PANOLA, Ala. — The dog-eared trailer that serves as the only convenience store within 20 miles of this blink-and-you-miss-it rural hamlet, population 144, is more than a place to stock up on life’s essentials. These days the store — or more precisely its proprietor, Dorothy Oliver — has become an unofficial logistics hub for African-American residents seeking the coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: In the U.S., cases tick upward again as variants spread and states lift restrictions.
description: The country averaged 61,545 cases last week, 11 percent more than the average two weeks earlier.
content: After weeks of decline followed by a steady plateau, coronavirus cases are rising again in the United States. Deaths are still decreasing, but the country averaged 61,545 cases last week, 11 percent more than the average two weeks earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson, Jack Ewing and Liz Alderman
title: The Swift Collapse of a Company Built on Debt
description: Greensill Capital promised a win-win for buyers and sellers, until it all fell apart, igniting concerns about opaque accounting practices.
content: LONDON — The courthouse should have already been closed for the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman
title: Would the Pandemic Stop Paul Theroux From Traveling?
description: No. Of course not.
content: For five days, Paul Theroux, the famous American travel writer, dined on hard-boiled eggs, microwaved dal and wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Robbins
title: In Montana, Bears and Wolves Become Part of the Culture Wars
description: The politics of predators seem poised to enter a new chapter in the state, which now seems intent on reviving some of the practices of a century ago that virtually exterminated wolves from Montana.
content: HELENA, Mont. — In addition to its spectacular landscape of mountains, rivers and prairie, Montana, the third least populous state in the country, has long been known for something else — wildlife policies that have protected animals of all sorts, including ones like grizzly bears and gray wolves that are often seen as threats to humans and to farming and ranching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leanne Brown
title: How to Save at the Grocery Store
description: Food is pleasure and connection for most of us. Staying within your budget can bring peace of mind and keep your overall spending on track.
content: How do you spend the right amount on food?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Madeleine Ngo
title: Many U.S. graduations are curtailed again, but some commencements will go on without guests.
description: Many universities stipulate that to participate in graduation, students must test negative for the coronavirus beforehand and have a record of adhering to campus restrictions.
content: Yale plans to hold a version of in-person graduation for the class of 2021 in May — with no guests allowed. Harvard is not even calling its commencement a “commencement.” It plans to hold virtual degree-granting ceremonies and, for the second year in a row, will postpone traditional festivities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 28, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 28, 2021.
content: A picture caption with an article on Page 7 about digital interactions between Broadway stars and fans misidentifies the digital event attended by the “Beetlejuice” actor Alex Brightman. It was a birthday party that included actors from other shows, not a “Beetlejuice” event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Eric Schmitt and Declan Walsh
title: As Militants Seize Mozambique Gas Hub, a Dash for Safety Turns Deadly
description: An agonizing choice for nearly 200 people holed up in a hotel as gunmen roamed unchecked: Wait overnight for rescue? Or make a run for it?
content: JOHANNESBURG — As gunshots rang out across a port town in northeastern Mozambique on Friday afternoon, nearly 200 people sheltering inside the Amarula Palma hotel confronted a devastating reality: The armed insurgents outside the hotel’s doors had all but taken control of the town and there was no one coming to save them any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Big Win for Marijuana
description: New York reaches a deal to legalize marijuana, and China strikes back against sanctions.
content: Good morning and happy Passover. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Gaffney
title: Reclaim Your Groove With an Online Concert
description: Looking for signs of a return to normal? Sitting back to enjoy a live-music performance might be a good place to start.
content: The performing arts have endured a year like no other, but the decimation of touring and in-person shows has in no way squelched music fans’ love of a live performance. And in many ways, the pandemic has yielded creative new ways for artists to engage with their listeners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: Explosion Rocks Indonesian Church Compound on Palm Sunday
description: No churchgoers were killed, but at least 19 people were injured, the police said. President Joko Widodo called it an act of terrorism.
content: An explosion shook a Roman Catholic cathedral compound in the eastern Indonesian city of Makassar on Sunday morning, shattering the calm of Palm Sunday, a holy day for Christians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morrigan McCarthy
title: At Mealtimes, Consider a Return to the Table
description: Have you been “zombie eating” during the pandemic? If you put down your phone or turn off the TV, you might enjoy your food a bit more.
content: If you have found yourself over the past year increasingly eating dinner in front of the TV, or scrolling endlessly through your phone over breakfast, you certainly are not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Testing, One, Two. Fans Flock to an Experimental Indoor Rock Concert.
description: An organizer said this Barcelona event, one of several planned in Europe, was “a small but important step toward normality.” The listeners there basked in being part of an audience again.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — Mireia Serret, a 21-year old student at the University of Barcelona, said that she was not a big fan of the band that played here on Saturday, nor does she normally like large crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: When Tragedy Strikes, What Does Criticism Have to Offer?
description: It’s easier to find meaning in fiction than in the senseless mass killings of our reality, which seem to render the critical perspective pointless, even silly, at times.
content: On Monday afternoon, before yet another mass shooting was reported in America, I finished “Blindness,” the 1995 novel by the Portuguese author José Saramago. I’d picked it up in preparation for a theatrical adaptation that is opening at the Daryl Roth Theater next month — what will be my first foray to a theater in what seems like ages. The novel had already been on my radar, ever since a friend described it to me with the word “disturbing” — or was it “distressing?” Either way, it sounded unforgettable and severe, and my ears immediately perked up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Flooding in Nashville Kills at Least 4 as Water Keeps Rising
description: Dozens of people were rescued as cars were swept away and neighborhoods were swamped. “We’re not out of the woods yet,” officials said, as water levels climbed on the Cumberland River.
content: NASHVILLE — Unrelenting rainfall in Nashville turned roads to rapids, sweeping vehicles off the streets and drowning a motorist who was carried away, one of at least four people killed during a storm that continued to threaten the city on Sunday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: These Shoes Contain a Drop of Human Blood. Nike Does Not Approve.
description: As a follow-up to its Jesus Shoes, the company MSCHF will sell 666 pairs of Satan Shoes in collaboration with the rapper Lil Nas X.
content: Some workplaces encourage employees to donate blood as an act of charity. But six workers at MSCHF, a quirky company based in Brooklyn that’s known for products like toaster-shaped bath bombs and rubber-chicken bongs, offered their blood for a new line of shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Syria says it will ration fuel as the economic toll of the blockage grows.
description: The government of Syria has said that it will begin rationing the use of fuel after the closure of the Suez Canal delayed the delivery of a critical shipment of oil to the war-torn nation.
content: The government of Syria has said that it will begin rationing the use of fuel after the closure of the Suez Canal delayed the delivery of a critical shipment of oil to the war-torn nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb and Scott Cacciola
title: These N.B.A. Contenders Just Got Better
description: A look at the league’s top-tier contenders after a busy period of player movement.
content: The N.B.A.’s trade deadline on Thursday featured more than a dozen trades — some surprising, some not so much. Several players named Gary were traded (Trent Jr., Clark, Harris). Miami was the biggest winner, acquiring Victor Oladipo and, separately, Nemanja Bjelica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Edith Prentiss, Fierce Voice for New York’s Disabled, Dies at 69
description: She was passionate — and relentless — about making the city she loved navigable for everyone.
content: Edith Prentiss, a fierce and fiery advocate for the disabled who fought to make the city she loved more navigable for everyone, died on March 16 at her home in the Washington Heights neighborhood of Manhattan. She was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brillian Bao and Kristine White
title: At least 36 states give clergy vaccine priority, for the risks they face and the example they set.
description: Public health officials are turning to frontline faith leaders to reduce vaccination hesitancy in their communities.
content: At least 36 states have made some members of the clergy eligible for a vaccine before the rest of the population, according to a New York Times survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Doc Severinsen Recalls High Notes, Low Notes and Everything in Between
description: The trumpeter and former “Tonight Show” bandleader tells tales from his personal life and his work with Johnny Carson in a new PBS documentary.
content: Doc Severinsen hadn’t been able to practice his trumpet in a couple of days, and by his own admission, it was making him irritable. “I’m getting a little bit antsy,” he said one afternoon earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: As Gonzaga Dominates, U.C.L.A Tops Alabama in an N.C.A.A. Thriller
description: Gonzaga is moving smoothly in its chase of an undefeated season. U.C.L.A. is also in the round of 8 after surging past Alabama in overtime.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Joel Ayayi, a junior guard from Bordeaux, France, with a sly grin and a silky jumper, fancies himself as l’enfant terrible of the Gonzaga men’s basketball team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough and Kenny Holston
title: Getting to Yes: A Nursing Home’s Mission to Vaccinate Its Hesitant Staff
description: Almost all of the residents at Forest Hills of D.C. got their initial Covid-19 shots in January. But nearly half of the staff there had declined. Would an effort to change their minds succeed?
content: WASHINGTON — The Covid-19 vaccine had finally come to Forest Hills of D.C., a nursing home in a prosperous neighborhood of the nation’s capital, but there was a problem. Though nearly all of the home’s residents agreed to get the shots, nearly half its 200 staff members declined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: An Online Museum Shows Life During Wartime
description: The new Museum of American War Letters is making a range of communications from battle zones available.
content: “Blew him in half, absolutely in half.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: In the Name of Love
description: Lynn Lempel has been busy as a … well, you know.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s always nice to see a familiar byline as we open our solving week, and this puzzle is by one of our veteran Monday constructors, Lynn Lempel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Rembrandt in the Blood’
description: No one had spotted a new painting by the Dutch master for four decades — until the scion of a storied Amsterdam family found two.
content: It was in the winter of 2016 that Jan Six, a Dutch art dealer based in Amsterdam, made a discovery that would upend his life. He was leafing through a Christie’s catalog when he spotted a painting featuring a young man wearing a dazed look, a lace collar and a proto-Led Zeppelin coif. Christie’s had labeled it a painting by one of Rembrandt’s followers, but Mr. Six knew it was by the Dutch master himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: After a Firefighter’s Death, His Son Gets a Truck Birthday Parade
description: Rows upon rows of police cars, fire trucks and construction vehicles showed up for Logan Lloyd’s 6th birthday, a day after his father was killed while battling a blaze at an assisted living center.
content: Matt Boney said a fire chief had grabbed him on Tuesday night as they prepared to pull the body of their fallen comrade, Jared Lloyd, from the rubble of an assisted living center in Rockland County, N.Y., where Mr. Lloyd had died trying to rescue residents from a fire hours earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 29, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: Start Retraining for Social Interactions
description: After a year spent social distancing, mask wearing and sheltering in place, the prospect of readjusting to in-person social engagements can be a daunting one.
content: As the days grow warmer and vaccination shots reach more arms, you may be looking ahead to getting out and about. An Axios-Ipsos poll released this month found that “the number of Americans engaging in social interactions outside the home is increasing.” And the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently issued new recommendations that individuals who have been vaccinated against the coronavirus can start to gather in small groups, without masks, offering a measure of hope in particular to those who have missed the intimacy of double dates and dinner parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Billions (Yes, Billions) of Cicadas Soon to Emerge From Underground
description: Swarms of cicadas, part of a group called Brood X, are expected to appear in 18 states in the next few weeks, just in time to help orchestrate the soundtrack of summer.
content: A few months of quarantine during the coronavirus pandemic? That’s nothing for a swarm of cicadas that have been underground since 2004.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky, Lila Allen and Lauren Messman
title: 16 Global Design Concepts for an Unpredictable Future
description: The challenges of the past year gave designers every reason to recede into the shadows, but creativity won’t be denied.
content: If anything, they are finding inspiration in global upheaval. From hundreds of possibilities, here are just a few examples we selected of projects begun or realized despite closed borders, disrupted supply chains and economic collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie G. Nelson, Emma Cott, Ben Laffin, Erik Ljung and Brian Dawson
title: Inside the Battle Over George Floyd Square
description: The trial over George Floyd’s death is underway in Minneapolis. What to do with his memorial site has become a controversy of its own.
content: The trial over George Floyd’s death is underway in Minneapolis. What to do with his memorial site has become a controversy of its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: At Least 4 People Killed in Nashville Floods
description: Heavy rainfall on Saturday night that continued into Sunday morning flooded roads and neighborhoods, prompting dozens of rescues. Flash flood warnings were still in effect on Sunday for parts of Middle Tennessee.
content: Heavy rainfall on Saturday night that continued into Sunday morning flooded roads and neighborhoods, prompting dozens of rescues. Flash flood warnings were still in effect on Sunday for parts of Middle Tennessee.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Christian Social Justice, Redux
description: Readers discuss the return of a movement to prominence in a charged era.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Country That Values Guns More Than Children’
description: A former school librarian recalls feeling panicked by an active-shooter drill that “felt all too real.” Also: Beach erosion on the Outer Banks; Amazon and organized labor.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
